title: Shifting within: creating change inside a corrupt system without losing ourselves
text:
Shifting within: creating change inside a corrupt system without losing ourselves

This post explores living in the contradiction: working to change harmful systems while knowing that those same systems help pay ourÂ bills.

I dream of a future where everyone has what they need and where design supports human and planetary flourishing. This vision fills me with hope while also making me acutely aware of the reality many designers face today. Our work is done within the dominant capitalist framework that prioritizes financial growth above all else, often at the expense of true flourishing. In this system, design has largely been co-opted as a tool for increasing profits, optimizing efficiency, and driving consumptionâ€Šâ€”â€Šrarely questioning the foundations of the systems itÂ serves.

As designers, we often find ourselves caughtÂ between:

  • The practical necessity of working within existing systems to earn a living and have immediate impact
  • The moral imperative to imagine and create fundamentally different systems that center human dignity, social justice, and ecological health
  • The professional challenges of balancing client expectations with our deeper values andÂ ethics
  • The emotional labor of holding hope for transformation while facing the limitations of incremental change

This reality creates a fundamental tension between â€œwithinâ€ and â€œbeyondâ€ We recognize the need for radical systems change while needing to function in the current system in order to pay our bills. These tensions arenâ€™t just philosophicalâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey manifest in everyday decisions about which projects to take on, how to approach design challenges, whose voices to amplify, and what futures we choose to help create. It raises questions about complicity, compromise, and the real possibilities for change within and beyond the systems weÂ inhabit.

As Iâ€™ve been thinking about a better future for and through design, Iâ€™ve been askingÂ myself:

How can we shift within the current system as we work to a betterÂ one?

In my explorations, Iâ€™ve found three different ways to shift within the current system: practicing harm reduction, building movements, and centering rest as a form of resistance here andÂ now.

1. Practice harm reduction

I think our role today is to practice harm reduction within the current system and minimize damage through immediate interventions like making existing services more accessible or policies more equitable, while simultaneously imagining and prototyping entirely new ways of organizing society, work, andÂ care.

One of the most accessible and powerful ways designers can practice harm reduction is by asking better, braver questions. Questions that slow down the pace of â€œsolutionismâ€œ and open space for reflection:

  • â€‹â€‹Who benefits from this designâ€Šâ€”â€Šand who might be excluded orÂ harmed?
  • What values are embedded in this solution?
  • What voices are missing from thisÂ process?
  • What assumptions are we making about users, needs, orÂ impact?
  • What happens when we ask â€œat what cost?â€ instead of just â€œhow mightÂ we?â€

Many of these questions were first introduced through The Design Justice Network. Their work centers principles and practices meant to shift what we work on, who our work is in service for, and how we do the work as designers. Design is often framed as a neutral tool for innovation, but this view ignores the power dynamics and inequalities baked into the systems we operate in. Practicing harm reduction means rejecting neutrality. It means acknowledging that our work participates in shaping the worldâ€Šâ€”â€Šoften in ways that reinforce existing hierarchies unless we actively pushÂ back.

When I think of design and its ability to create change, I think about the dance between possibility and responsibility. Our work can either harm or heal. A few months ago, I posted this on Linkedin â€œGood design is a dance between curiosity and criticality. As designers, we love asking, â€œhow might weâ€ but we also have to ask â€œat what cost.â€ Design can heal but it can also harm. As designers, we must balance possibilities and responsibilities. We must be curious AND critical.â€

2. Build movements

Building movement is another way we can create change within the current system. When we take a look around, we see many movements and organizations working to fight the current system and help us live better within them and throughout history movements like Black Lives Matters, Disability Rights Movement, Gay Rights Movements, etc. have paved the way for many of the rights we have today. Within design, Design Justice movements, Trauma-informed design, etc. have made our profession more accessible while questioning the powers at play. Movements are ways to challenge the current systems from within and hopefully dismantle them in theÂ future.

Many movements we champion today exist precisely because the current system doesnâ€™t allow for equality and justice. Feminism responds to gender inequality. Disability rights acts respond to systems that donâ€™t accommodate differences. In an ideal future, we wonâ€™t need these movementsâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut until we get to a liberated future, our job is to reduce harm through movement building.

Movements vs.Â identity

In her book Hospicing Modernity, Vanessa Machado de Oliveira (formerly Vanessa Andreotti) shares an anecdote around movement building. During a panel discussion on global feminism, she was asked what role global feminisms will play in decolonial futures. She responded: â€œIf we still had to talk about global feminisms in a supposedly decolonized future, something would have definitely gone wrong.â€ She continued, â€œWhen I identify as a feminist, I see the point of my role as working myself out of the need for feminist critiques in the future, rather than indefinitely investing in a collective identity.â€

Machado de Oliveira highlights an important difference between a movement and an identity. While many movement help us fight for ours and others rights, clinging to the cause as identities CAN limit our ability to let go of the movement when they no longer serve the intended cause anymore. It can also keep us from connecting across differences and reject anymore who does not identify in the same way. As the writer and activist adrienne maree brownÂ writes:

â€œWe live inside of interlocking systems of oppression. These systems only work because we uphold them inside ourselves and between us. Rather than canceling each other for every way that weâ€™re embodying the systems, we need to help break each other out of these systems and find ways to course correct for our country and our species together. When we turn on each other, the systems actually persist and they just go elsewhere. But when we actually heal each other and bring it all into the light, those systems become irrelevant. Thatâ€™s what we actually need right now. For the planetâ€™s sake and for our life on it, we need to hold on to each other and grow ourÂ soul.â€

When we create together we transform individual healing into collective progress. By turning toward one another, we can challenge the system and together create something that supports the well-being ofÂ all.

3. Rest as resistance

In order to continue to reduce harm and build movements that fight the current system, we need to rest. Poet, performance artist, and activist Trisha Hersey promotes how â€œrest is resistanceâ€. In her book by the same name she explains that we can reclaim our sense of worth by resisting the grind culture and choosing rest. She positions rest as a human rightâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot something that needs to be earned. Her book was transformative for me. I found the book in a time where I was working hard to reach new heights while ignoring burnout signs from my body and my mind. It helped me evaluate where I was pushing beyond my own boundaries and how it kept me from being able to fight forÂ others.

Resistance is different from resilience. It doesnâ€™t tell us to push through or become stronger than the system. Rather, it helps us unlearn what weâ€™ve been taught and resist whatâ€™s being reinforced about hard work through the larger paradigm. The rejection of hustle culture has been embraced by many. Itâ€™s not just a way to reclaim our worth but also a way to wake up and see clearly how the current culture of productivity, capitalism, and speed harms both ourselves and theÂ planet.

Centering rest as a radical act can help us survive with a little more ease in a system that wants to exploitÂ us.

From Within to Beyond: Bridging the present and the future through The AdjacentÂ Possible

Between â€œwithinâ€ and â€œbeyondâ€ lies what innovation theorist Steven Johnson calls â€œthe Adjacent Possibleâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šspaces of possibility that become available from our current position. These are the opportunities that exist not in some distant utopia but in the immediate next steps we canÂ take.

In the book Good Ideas (shop at your local book shop), Johnson writes â€œThe adjacent possible is a kind of shadow future, hovering on the edges of the present state of things, a map of all the ways in which the present can reinvent itself.â€ Each moment in our history unlocks new doors of adjacent possibilities.

The Adjacent Possible reminds us that transformation occurs not in sudden leaps but through continuous exploration of emerging possibilities. Itâ€™s about finding footholds for change within our present reality that can lead toward more substantive shifts.

Audre Lorde said: â€œAt the same time as weâ€™re surviving in the mouth of the dragon, we also need to be feeding our vision.â€ Surviving within the mouth of the dragon means practicing harm reduction, building movements alongside others, and resting as a form of resistance. These actions can open up a space for us to free our vision of a better tomorrow. Letâ€™s act together.

Resources & Inspiration

  • Adrienne Maree Brownâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAuthor of Emergent Strategy and Pleasure Activism, exploring transformative justice, imagination, and movement building.
  • Vanessa Machado de Oliveira (formerly Vanessa Andreotti)â€Šâ€”â€ŠHospicing Modernity: A powerful book on navigating collapse, decolonization, and reimagining systems.
  • Bayo Akomolafeâ€Šâ€”â€ŠPhilosopher, poet, and author of We Will Dance with Mountains: Vunja, exploring post-activism and new world-making.
  • We Have to Reimagine Our World with Indy Johar (Louisiana Channel)â€Šâ€”â€ŠA visionary architect speaks on redesigning institutions for systemic transformation.
  • The Most Creative Look to the Future from UN Global Pulseâ€Šâ€”â€ŠA report on how creativity and artistic practice can catalyze systemicÂ change.
  • From What Is to What If by Rob Hopkinsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠA hopeful manifesto on unleashing imagination to shape more resilient, just, and beautiful futures.
  • Liberating Structuresâ€Šâ€”â€ŠPractical microstructures for group collaboration, innovation, and participatory change-making.

Shifting within: creating change inside a corrupt system without losing ourselves was originally published in UX Collective on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

title: How AI writing tools fail to speak to writers
text:
How AI writing tools fail to speak to writers

Seven design insights from taking Grammarly ads (too) seriously.

Three weeks ago, YouTube finally decided that I must be interested in writing. Fair enough: Iâ€™m a Human-Computer Interaction professor researching writing tools and the impact of AI. Soon, my feed filled with Grammarly adsâ€Šâ€”â€Šand I started reflecting on their curious messages.

What if we took AI writing tool ads seriously?

Ads may seem an odd source for design reflection. Yet they are highly intentional design artefacts because they are expensive and compete for attention. They are forced to distil a designâ€™s essential features and choose concrete values to highlight. This makes them spotlights on how a design wants to be seen and understood.

The key insight from my anecdotal ad-vestigation:

As portrayed in their ads, these AI tools address people who donâ€™t value writing for its intellectual or creative demands, and thus miss its opportunities forÂ growth.

In response, I outline seven design insights and questions to inspire alternative directions for your next (AI) writing tool design. They are organised into two parts: concepts and useÂ cases.

Concepts of human-AI interaction in writingÂ tools

The ads reveal several recurring themes in how humanâ€“AI interaction is framed within writingÂ tools.

Interaction paradigm: What exactly is anÂ agent?

Some ads present Grammarly as an app, others as an agent. Interestingly, in both cases, they depict a toolbar or sidebar UI element. The only ad that shows a chat does not use the word agent, although chatting feels more characteristic of an agent than toolbars. This leaves open how Grammarly itself understands and operationalises â€œagent-nessâ€, at least in the ads I encountered.

Questions for your design: Which interaction design, offering which (AI) capabilities, would make your system an agent rather than a tool, from a userâ€™s perspective? And how does that serve your designÂ goals?

Task delegation: Avoiding writing withÂ AI

Mandy ads emphasise the appeal of delegating writing tasks to AI to save time and effort. Examples include slogans like â€œYour work-life balance just got more manageableâ€ and â€œSound natural and polished without extra effortâ€. One ad even promotes a â€œHumanizer agentâ€ to â€œEliminate robotic phrasingâ€. This likely targets those disappointed by past results with AI. Another ad mentions an â€œAI lineupâ€, implying delegation of writing to multipleÂ agents.

Across these examples, the ads frame writing as labour to be avoided. As someone with a deep interest in writing, this does not speak to me atÂ all.

Alternative design direction: How might we design tools that let writers delegate the tasks that distract from writing, rather than writingÂ itself?

Writing stages: AI wants to help everywhere

Several ads stress the userâ€™s involvement through phrases that highlight â€œyourâ€ contribution. Examples include â€œkeeping ownership of your ideasâ€, â€œmake your voice resonate with readersâ€, â€œYour best work deserves a powerful stageâ€, and â€œSee specific ways to strengthen your essayâ€. Across idea, voice, work, and essay, these ads imply that AI will assist at any stage ofÂ writing.

Together, these ads position AI as always present, with no clear roles or boundaries. This might be less appealing to expert writers who know their workflows well.

Alternative design direction: What if we made it a deliberate design goal to constrain AI to a specific role, rather than letting it do everything? And how might we empower writers to shape the scope of AI functionality and its integration into UIs and workflows themselves?

Cognitive processes: Typing but notÂ writing

One ad promised to â€œGet Effective, Mistake-Free Writing Every Time You Typeâ€. This framing turns the user into a receiver of writing from an unspecified source, implied to be AI. The user is not entirely passive, though: They still â€œtypeâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šbut they do not â€œwriteâ€. This is a key difference. In the cognitive process model of writing, typing aligns with the transcriber, the most mechanical of the three processes. The other two are proposer (generating ideas) and translator (expressing them in words). The adâ€™s message thus assumes users who prefer to avoid the more creative efforts ofÂ writing.

Alternative design direction: How might we design (AI) writing tools that help users actively explore their own ideas and expression, instead of passively receiving prefabricated language from theÂ system?

Use cases for AI writingÂ tools

The ads primarily target two audiences: students and professionals. Moreover, ideation appears as a third use case across bothÂ groups.

Ideationâ€Šâ€”â€Šwithout exploration

Several ads promise help with finding ideas at the start of a writing project. Examples include â€œSay goodbye to blank-page scaries and jump-start ideas fasterâ€, â€œStart your best draft with this AI lineupâ€, and â€œJump-Start Ideas With Grammarlyâ€™s AI Brainstorming Featuresâ€. The latter ad shows a brainstorming button that generates high-level essay content for a user-provided topic. I like that it offers possible directions without dictating details. However, the featureâ€™s UI design limits exploration and iteration. It is crammed into a chatbox pop-up with no space and editing capabilities to compare or iterate onÂ ideas.

As shown in the ad, users are expected to immediately copy an AI-provided idea. This workflow seems unlikely to appeal to people who enjoy exploring many ideas before committing one to theÂ page.

Alternative design direction: How might we design for a closer integration of ideation and writing? Of canvas and page? What if the AIâ€™s role were to facilitate transitions between these processes, or to provide a substrate for exploration and iteration, rather than simply generating text toÂ copy?

Communication: Is AI polish all youÂ need?

Another group of ads focuses on writing as communication, such as â€œPut your best foot forwardâ€, â€œSend the right messageâ€, â€œGet heads nodding on your first email instead of your fifthâ€, and â€œCommunicate clearly, come across as you intend, and strengthen work relationshipsâ€. Fittingly, these ads feature people rather than interfaces, highlighting the promise that AI will help the user be perceived positively.

However, the opposite can also be true: When a message is perceived as AI-generated, it can decrease trust. It remains unclear how the design mitigates these risks. The existence of a â€œHumanizer Agentâ€ in another ad supports this: Why design features that require the user to also â€œhumanizeâ€ theÂ text?

Alternative design direction: How might we design tools with a nuanced understanding of the social nature of writing in focus, rather than assuming that AI polish is all youÂ need?

Learning: Grades overÂ growth

Grammarlyâ€™s YouTube playlist for students focuses on performance markers. Its slogans include â€œWork faster and smarterâ€, â€œMake the gradeâ€, â€œSubmit high-quality work for schoolâ€, and â€œCraft your success storyâ€. The last one features a time-travel plot in which a student learns that â€œeveryoneâ€™s using itâ€, and joining in will turn him into a CEO later in life. As an educator, I find this focus troublesome because the ads never portray students motivated by genuine learning.

Identifying this as the best marketing strategy for a writing tool may reveal more about cultural views of education than about the tool itself. A behind-the-scenes video titled â€œHow to succeed in schoolâ€ makes this even clearer: It interviews actors from the ads, who give personal advice such as â€œdonâ€™t take it so seriouslyâ€ and â€œpeople put too much emphasis on studyingâ€.

In contrast, the ad â€œEdit Essays Fasterâ€ shows a degree of introspection through interaction with AI. A student reflects on edit suggestions: â€œThatâ€™s true. This is much better. You know, I didnâ€™t know my writing contained so many run-on sentences until I started using Grammarly.â€

While this moment hints at learning, whatâ€™s missing are features that help students turn such insights into lasting improvements.

Alternative design direction: How might we design (AI) writing tools that help users develop their writing skills, rather than replaceÂ them?

Takeaways

Marketed in these ways, AI writing tools seem to address people who donâ€™t value writing for its intellectual or creative demands. Yet those demands offer opportunities for thinking, expression, personal insight, and skill development. I suspect this mismatch is a part of why AI tools can miss the mark withÂ writers.

If we read ads as reflections of underlying design assumptions, they tell us something about tool design itself, not merely marketing strategy. This view motivated the questions above, pointing to alternative design directions.

Nevertheless, thereâ€™s a difference between how a tool is advertised and how it can be leveraged. In this spirit, and as a small experiment, I edited this article with Grammarly. I had a good experience with it in this limited role. I even liked some of the constraints of the free account: It marked sentences for me to revisit, yet hid the AI suggestions. I like to think that this prompted my own thinking. Some features, like â€œexpert reviewsâ€, also seem designed to generate questions rather than only answers. More broadly, Iâ€™m curious to see upcoming updates, from acquiring Superhuman to proactive agents, and how these will be advertisedâ€Šâ€”â€Šand toÂ whom.

Resources

These references provide further reading on the mentioned concepts and suggested design directions:

  • Perceptions of AI in email writing and in other interpersonal communication
  • Creativity support tools designed for more than productivity and for empowering writers
  • What if AI tools were designed to center writersâ€™ own creative decisions?
  • The cognitive process model of writing and the role of AI suggestions therein
  • Combining canvas and page UIs for writing with AIÂ features

How AI writing tools fail to speak to writers was originally published in UX Collective on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

title: A Hippocratic Oath for techâ€¦ with teeth
text:
A Hippocratic Oath for techâ€¦ with teeth

From Frankensteinâ€™s dilemma to the Greek agora, history offers blueprints for building tech industry legitimacy.

I was reading Frankenstein to my son last week (as one does in the days leading up to Halloween). As he fell asleep, I was struck by a thought. The â€œmove fast and break thingsâ€ ethos of the last two decades in tech is remarkably similar to the core themes of the 200+ y/o Shelley classic. The story of a creator obsessed with his own genius, blind to the consequences, who unleashes a powerful, uncontrolled creation into the world and then abdicates all responsibility for the harm it causes? An apt comparison, indeed.

Victor Frankensteinâ€™s great folly lay not in his ambition, but in his abdication. Horrified that he â€œhad turned loose into the world a depraved wretch,â€ he ran. He left his creation to be feared and misunderstood by a society that was not prepared forÂ it.

This is the dilemma of the modern tech profession. We, the architects of the digital commons, have acted with the same hubris. We build systems optimized for profit and engagement, unleash them upon society, and then hide behind a structure of diffused responsibility when systemic harms emerge (teen mental health crisis, political polarization, mass addiction, erosion of privacy).

Which brings me to another idea that occurred around the same time: â€œTerms of Service.â€ No, Iâ€™m not talking about the little box you check, having not read the thousands of words of dense, technical jargon. That is a symptom of theÂ disease.

Iâ€™m talking about flipping this very concept on its head- an enforceable â€œTerms of Serviceâ€ pledge to be taken by tech professionals (myself included, as a UX and brand strategist): an oath to address â€œFrankensteinâ€™s dilemmaâ€ and finally take responsibility for our (co)creation.

From Open Commons to Unregulated Market

This call to action is made urgent by the industryâ€™s own evolution. The ethos of the early internet was rooted in the promise of a decentralized, open commons: a â€œfreedom to connect, to innovate, to program, without asking permission.â€

Unfortunately, that ethos has been superseded. The commons has been enclosed and commercialized. Todayâ€™s dominant platforms are not public utilities but engines of monetization, driven by an attention economy that treats human focus as its primary resource.

In his book Technofeudalism, Yanis Varoufakis describes how

â€œcloud capitalistsâ€¦ have mutated into something far grander: techno-lords presiding over cloud fiefs and accumulating a new form of rent- cloud rent-extracted from a new class of serf: the cloudÂ serf.â€

The fundamental change in purpose- from a tool for communication to a system for extraction- is precisely why the field is overdue for an ethical overhaul.

Precedents for Accountability

This is not the first â€œwild westâ€ in professional historyâ€¦

Imagine you are a stonemason in ancient Greece, struck by a fever that will not break. You seek help in the agora, but the marketplace of â€œhealersâ€ is a chaotic spectacle.

One man offers a poultice of herbs mixed with magical charms. Another, a priest, insists your illness is a divine punishment and demands a sacrifice. A third offers a potion, but youâ€™ve heard whispers that some such men are not above accepting payment to administer poison. Who do you trust with your life when there is no standard to distinguish a healer from a charlatan? This was the reality of the â€œmedical professionâ€ in Greece, circa the 5th centuryÂ BCE.

Enter the Hippocratic Oath: a radical intervention with a practical purpose and a lasting impact. A group of practitioners set themselves apart with a binding commitment to â€œabstain from whatever is deleterious and mischievousâ€ and to act in the patientâ€™s best interest, forging a pact of trust with a public desperate forÂ it.

Centuries later, other professions forged their own pacts. The Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer, along with the conferral of an Iron Ring, was born from the 1907 Quebec Bridge collapse, which killed 75 workers due to design flaws. While the legend that the first rings were made from the bridgeâ€™s wreckage is an embellishment, its endurance speaks to the professionâ€™s embrace of a foundational lesson in humility. Similarly, the legal and financial professions bind practitioners as â€˜officers of the courtâ€™ or with a â€˜fiduciary dutyâ€™, a legal standard obligating them to act in their clientâ€™s best interest, not theirÂ firmâ€™s.

In all cases, these oaths provide a higher authority to which the professional must answer, overriding the demands of a boss or a project budget. The tech industry, while relatively nascent, operates as a great exception.

Built on what Harvard Professor Shoshana Zuboff definesÂ as

â€œthe unilateral claiming of private human experience as free raw material for translation into behavioral data,â€

our current model of â€œsurveillance capitalismâ€(Zuboff) is not an inevitable result of technology, but a specific â€œeconomic creationâ€ that has thrived in secrecy and in the absence of law and regulation.

The resultant system of unchecked growth without accountability now translates into our crisis of governance. Our informational reality and civic lives are predominately ruled by algorithms optimized not for truth, but for profit. In this economy, polarizing content is the most engaging and therefore the most profitable. Research confirmed that when Facebookâ€™s algorithm (optimized for user engagement) was changed to boost posts with high emotional reactions, it â€œinadvertently promoted toxic and anger-inducing content.â€

Many compare the tech landscape to a â€œpre-reckoningâ€ Big Tobacco. A more useful comparison, however, might be the pharmaceutical industry. After the thalidomide disaster of the 1960s caused thousands of birth defects, governments began requiring â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ of a drugâ€™s safety and efficacy before it reaches theÂ public.

We do not knowingly allow drug companies to â€œmove fast and break thingsâ€ with public health. Yet with technology, we continually do. Corporations treat multi-billion-dollar fines as a fractional â€œcost of doing business.â€ In 2023, the five largest tech firms were fined a combined $3.04 billion. They earned enough revenue to pay that entire sum in just over sevenÂ days.

The Architecture of Diffused Responsibility

The modern tech company is a marvel of diffused responsibility, a psychological phenomenon where individuals in a group feel less personal accountability. The UX designer optimizes for engagement. The engineer for stability. The product manager for growth. No single person can be held responsible for the systemic harms thatÂ emerge.

This is the systemâ€™s genius: it scales profit and impact while atomizing responsibility.

A new oath, therefore, cannot be a passive pledge. It must be an active, professional tool that empowers the practitioner to fight this diffusion. It must grant tech workers the formal standing to ask questions, the right to see data, and the power to refuse; not as a malcontent, but as a professional upholding theirÂ code.

Consider the designer asked to create a notification system using intermittent variable rewards (the same mechanism as a slot machine) to maximize engagement. Ethical UX design principles dictate that a practitioner must â€œdo no harmâ€ and put the userâ€™s needs first, but it would require something closer to a â€œMandate of Inquiryâ€ to fully empower the designer to ask: â€œHave we researched the potential impact of this on teen anxiety? Can I see that data before proceeding?â€ Under a protected oath, the designer is no longer a troublesome employee, but a professional upholding a standard.

It is crucial to distinguish such a framework as a set of enforceable rights, not as another aspirational pledge. The landscape is littered with â€œfeel-goodâ€ oaths and top-down corporate principles published by the very companies causing harm. These top-down models are ultimately toothless because they disempower the individual. They are tools for legal compliance and public relations, not for the practitioner in the â€œengineÂ room.â€

Even our most evolved professional codes, such as those from the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM), are largely silent on the employer-employee power dynamic. They are excellent at describing a practitionerâ€™s duty- to prioritize the public good, to â€œavoid harmâ€, and to â€œchallenge unethical rules,â€ but they provide no tool or protection to do so against a conflicting order from management.

In other words, they tell the engineer to wave a flag at the runaway train, but offer no way to stop it. The practitioner who follows this duty is often the one who gets steamrolled, fired as a â€œdissenting employeeâ€ with little recourse.

The following Mandates, therefore, propose a fundamental shift: from a passive duty to an active power. They are designed to arm the practitioner for that inevitable moment of conflict. While as yet imperfect and conceptual, they are intended to spark necessary conversation about what a framework of enforceable and protected ethics must look like, and how we, as a profession, can begin to implement it.

The Architectâ€™s Mandate: A ProposedÂ Code

A functional oath for a tech professional would be less a pledge and more a formal declaration of professional obligations:

I. The Mandate ofÂ Inquiry

I shall have the protected right to ask â€œWhy?â€; to perform a root cause analysis on the intent behind the features I am asked to build. I will not be satisfied with metrics of â€œengagementâ€ as a substitute for humanÂ value.

  • This mandate is a direct antidote to the â€œarchitecture of diffused responsibilityâ€. While existing codes suggest practitioners should â€œreflect upon the wider impacts of their workâ€ or â€œtalk across teamsâ€, this provides a formal, protected right to demand answers and data, piercing the veil of organizational siloing.

II. The Mandate of Consequence

I shall have the right to access any and all research on the likely human impact of my work before it is deployed. I pledge to place the long-term well-being of the user above the short-term metrics of the platform.

  • This right is a novel mechanism for accountability. While human rights organizations often partner with engineers to analyze data and ethical frameworks discuss organizational â€œtransparencyâ€, no code grants the individual practitioner an affirmative right to access internal impact research before a productâ€™s release.

III. The Mandate ofÂ Refusal

I shall not be compelled to design, build, or deploy systems that I believe, in my professional judgment, are designed to exploit human vulnerabilities, erode agency or privacy, or amplify division. I will have the protected right to refuse such work without fear of retaliation.

  • This mandate radically expands the existing â€œright to refuseâ€ work. Current legal protections are almost exclusively limited to situations of â€œimminent dangerâ€ of â€œdeath or serious injuryâ€. This proposes a new, professional standard of refusable psycho-social harm, and demands explicit protection from retaliation for what amounts to secular, professional â€œconscientious objectionâ€.

IV. The Mandate of Precedence

I pledge to hold my duty to the public- their safety, their agency, and their mental well-being- as paramount, above my duty to my employerâ€™s stock price or my projectâ€™s quarterly goals.

  • This is the foundational principle of all mature professional codes. The National Society of Professional Engineers, for example, states that the â€œhighest ethical obligation is to protect the public health and safetyâ€. This mandate affirms that this established principle must finally be applied to the digitalÂ world.

V. The Mandate of Testimony

I shall have the protected right to bear witness to systemic public harm caused by a product I helped create, even after its release. My professional duty to warn the public shall supersede any non-disclosure agreement or corporate policy, and I shall not be subject to retribution for this testimony.

  • This is a potent synthesis of legal and ethical precedent. It argues that a tech professionalâ€™s â€œduty to warnâ€ the public of danger, a duty that supersedes confidentiality in medicine and traditional engineering- must also supersede a non-disclosure agreement or policy. While whistleblower laws already protect reporting of illegal activity and courts can compel testimony, this mandate seeks to extend that protection to testimony regarding systemic public harm that is not yet explicitly illegal.

VI. The Mandate ofÂ Audit

I shall have the protected right to audit the data sets and models I am asked to use before deployment. I will have the right to test for, document, and mitigate algorithmic bias, even if it conflicts with a projectâ€™s timeline or statedÂ goals.

  • This mandate targets a well-documented harm: AI systems that perpetuate and amplify societal biases. An algorithm is often â€œonly as good as the data that was used to train [it]â€. While some laws require top-down corporate â€œbias auditsâ€, this mandate grants the right to the practitioner, empowering them to test models and retrain or suspend biased algorithms as a matter of professional practice.

VII. The Mandate of Sustainable Design

I shall have the protected right to refuse work that I believe, in my professional judgment, intentionally implements planned obsolescence or demonstrably contributes to environmental degradation.

  • The tech industry is a massive contributor to e-waste and environmental harm, often by design (a â€œdeliberate industrial strategyâ€). This mandate extends the â€œright to refuseâ€ beyond immediate human danger to include systemic environmental danger, empowering engineers to advocate for sustainable â€œgreenâ€ engineering principles and refuse to participate in practices they know to be destructive.

The framework outlined here is not a plea for rebellion. If the â€œmove fast and break thingsâ€ era was marked by a defiant, adolescent, Frankenstein-esque hubris, this proposal is (conversely) a declaration of industry maturation. It is our chance to act on what Frankenstein only briefly glimpsed long after abandoning his creation, when he confessed,

â€œFor the first time, also, I felt what the duties of a creator towards his creatureÂ wereâ€¦â€

A codified set of principles, with the ultimate goal of legal enactment, is what separates a collection of atomized employees from a unified profession. A single person can be fired; a profession with a shared, legally-enforceable code of conduct hasÂ power.

We are not at the mercy of an unregulated â€œtech monsterâ€ beyond our control. We are its architects and gatekeepers. This is the moment we stop abdicating and choose to fulfill the duties of aÂ creator.

This is the blueprint. It is time to take ownership.

I invite a public critique of these mandates from all professionals in the field. Join the conversation in the responses below.

A Hippocratic Oath for techâ€¦ with teeth was originally published in UX Collective on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

title: AI gardens, Sora icon, Claude Code & Figma MCP, error handling UX
text:
AI gardens, Sora icon, Claude Code & Figma MCP, error handling UX

Weekly curated resources for designersâ€Šâ€”â€Šthinkers andÂ makers.

â€œThe 1930s were ripe for innovation, during the thick of the Second Industrial Revolution. Designers were captivated by the new technology of plywood bending, which allowed previously impossible forms toÂ emerge.â€

How Estonia, AI gardens, and plywood make designers prolific â†’
By DarrenÂ Yeo

Editor picks

  • Can technology fix voting? â†’
    The impact digitization of electoral process can actually have.
    By Allan MacDonald
  • The paradox of tolerance â†’
    Karl Popper and the extinction of the rational mind.
    By NateÂ Sowder
  • Hoping for the long-term â†’
    An interview with Alexander Rose.
    By daveÂ hoffer

The UX Collective is an independent design publication that elevates unheard design voices and helps designers think more critically about theirÂ work.

Why Gothic endures in visual cultureÂ â†’

Make meÂ think

  • Original work is now an endangered species â†’
    â€œOpen Twitter, LinkedIn, or any blog platform. Scroll for five minutes. Youâ€™ll see the same articles rewritten 50 different ways. Headlines like: morning routines of successful people, is coding dead in the age of AI, top programming languages to learn this year, how to stop procrastinating once and for all, ChatGPT will revolutionize everything, side hustles you can startÂ today.â€
  • Creating prototypes constrained by the medium not our skills or understanding â†’
    â€œBut what if the limitations in the mind of a designer are their own and not the mediums? What if they donâ€™t get how it works? What if they do but canâ€™t make itÂ work?â€
  • Weâ€™ve all bought into technosolutionism, but we can opt out â†’
    â€œTechnosolutionism is a narrow perspective on progress and innovation, deeply rooted in the logic of capitalism: an innovation is pursued if it is the path of least resistance toward the largest financial return.â€

Little gems thisÂ week

The horrors of designing for omniscience â†’
By TristanÂ Free

Sora app icon: a visual breakdown â†’
By AdirÂ SL

Designing for emotional dependence â†’
By Ian Batterbee

Tools and resources

    By Iasonas Georgiadis
  • Design prompt-building interfaces â†’
    How to help users articulate their intents strategically.
    By SenÂ Lin
  • Error handling â†’
    UX design patterns to help users.
    By MatanÂ Rosen

title: How to nail onboardingâ€Šâ€”â€Ša case study of Runna
text:
How to nail onboardingâ€Šâ€”â€Ša case study of Runna

How to nail onboardingâ€Šâ€”â€Ša case study ofÂ Runna

Lessons in clarity, confidence and community

Nearly 1 billion runs were recorded on Strava inÂ 2024.

Targeting runners is a bigÂ market.

And itâ€™s a market thatâ€™s growingâ€Šâ€”â€Šaccording to Strava, running was the â€˜fastest growing sport globallyâ€™ with â€˜Gen Z turning to running to create community and connectionâ€™.

Which is the winning strategy for coaching appÂ Runna.

If you run, youâ€™ve probably heard of Runna. The consumer app is all over Instagram, TikTok, and Strava, with 48,000+ ratings at 4.9 stars on the app store. The Reddit community alone now has around 47,000Â members.

Officially launching in March 2022, Runna reached 7,000 paying subscribers a year later and has since helped millions of runners complete their firstÂ race.

In April 2025, Runna was acquired by Stava for an unknown amount. Though estimates are around Â£150 million, based on a 30X return to early crowdfunding investors, who invested when it was valued at Â£5 million (30 X Â£5M =Â Â£150M).

Thatâ€™s when I decided to see what all the hype wasÂ about.

The acquisition caught my eye, and so did the fact that my friends had just signed me up for a half-marathon ğŸ«  As a Strava paying subscriber, I got the email about a Strava Ã— Runna bundle, it made sense to give it aÂ go.

And this is that story: my journey through Runnaâ€™s incredible onboarding.

Weâ€™ll see three big lessons across the onboarding flow, covering:

  • Why most product marketing tests fail to have an impact, but Runnaâ€™s packs aÂ punch
  • Where user-generated content and community can come into onboarding
  • How certain industries need a longer onboarding process

By the end weâ€™ll see that thereâ€™s nothing flashy about Runnaâ€™s onboarding. It just makes you believe you can actually doÂ it.

Weâ€™ll also see just how well I ran according to my planÂ ğŸ‘€

Letâ€™s jump straight into lesson one, starting from the first thing we see: a welcome screen carousel.

Lesson 1) Show your productÂ clearly

Most apps try to look impressive. Runna just tries to makeÂ sense.

When I open the app on my phone for the first time, I see an onboarding carousel which looks slightly old-school, but I loveÂ it.

The classic saying is that â€˜no one reads an onboarding carouselâ€™.

Which, in my experience is halfÂ true.

Studies have shown users donâ€™t have time to read: most people read 28% of the words on a page; 20% is moreÂ likely.

However, Iâ€™ve added a carousel before a paywall before and it improved conversion to trial. So thereâ€™s something to be said for adding extra context for customers.

In my view, Runnaâ€™s carousel works here. It does three things reallyÂ well:

  • It runs through screens like an Instagram story (no tapping required)
  • Thereâ€™s very few words (max 9 in each headline)
  • Imagery does the heavyÂ lifting

The Instagram-style story creates a variable reward ğŸ§  as you donâ€™t know whatâ€™s coming next. It also follows a common consumer app mental model which works well in thisÂ context.

What stands out here is the imagery. From the second carousel screenshot, itâ€™s clear to me what a â€˜personalized running planâ€™ might lookÂ like.

As someone who gets injured all the time and has no real game plan for running, this structure, clarity and format made me sigh withÂ relief.

It created a mini-magic-moment for me earlyÂ on.

On the fourth screenshot, my running injuries came toÂ life:

Runna has used the most common running injury (Achilles Tendinitis) as an example, with microÂ copy:

  • Get back to running quickly and carefully
  • Returning to running post-injury

They know that this is one of the biggest fears, frustrations, or anxieties that holds people back from running. Whether itâ€™s past injuries or future injuries, with these images, Runna is signalling:

Weâ€™ve gotÂ you

Does this impact conversion? Hard to say. My gut saysÂ no.

In my experience, Iâ€™ve rarely seen adding imagery into onboarding improve conversion.

Thatâ€™s because itâ€™s really hard to do well. You need to have excellent image designers and really think about what will make people have a lightbulb moment. Imagery needs toÂ be:

  • Easy to scan, easy toÂ see
  • Use specific, realÂ examples
  • Be able to be understood in a momentâ€™sÂ glance

Thatâ€™s a toughÂ order.

Lesson 2) Bring your marketing inside yourÂ product

Runnaâ€™s onboarding starts long before download. Its community and content seep straight into the productÂ journey.

The first obvious thing I noticed is the authentic lifestyle imagery and social proof throughout theÂ flow.

After the carousel, I see a load of smiling women and men I want to be friends with sitting on a parkÂ bench.

Further into onboarding, after I select the run Iâ€™m doing, I see 230 other little avatars ready to run withÂ me.

There are little signals of value add hereÂ too:

  • Date
  • Location
  • Run type = flat (thankÂ god)

Before this onboarding flow, I hadnâ€™t checked the run route for the run Iâ€™dÂ booked.

With these details (flat â€˜elevation of 34 metersâ€™ & â€˜230 others runningâ€™), the app has calmed some anxieties around being fit enough for hills and showed me otherâ€™s are doing it too. Quietly reassuring me:

You gotÂ this

And it continuesâ€¦

At the end of onboarding, I see more runnersÂ ğŸ‘€

Notice how the human imageryÂ varies:

  • Full screen vs. small avatars vs.Â videos
  • Stylised shoots, vs â€˜taken on the runâ€™Â vibes
  • Background gradient fade or spotlight image

Whatâ€™s curious is that these touch points are littered throughout. There are 30 screens I see in onboarding before I see my plan on the homepage.

Hereâ€™s a summary (as I know the above image is too smallÂ ğŸ¥´):

In terms of where the imagery sits, thereâ€™s imagery beginning, middle (almost) and end of onboarding. With a big cluster near theÂ paywall.

What I see here: a product direction that knows community is important. And an onboarding funnel that matches the acquisition funnel (influencer marketing, user-generated content in ads, reddit communities).

Whilst hard to execute, Iâ€™ve heard of experiments showing that matching ad creative and copy at the top of the funnel to the product journey, from onboarding to homepage, can improve conversion to paid and retention.

Lesson 3) Design for confidence, notÂ speed

Everyone hasÂ fears.

My fears are around running (and theÂ dark).

The key doubts on my mind coming into thisÂ were:

  • Can I run this run Iâ€™veÂ booked?
  • Will my old injuries resurface?
  • Will I get new injuries?
  • Will I get faster? Can I run under 2Â hours?
  • Can I fit this into my workÂ week?
  • Will this app work with my garmin and strava setÂ up?

By the end of my 12-minute-long onboarding, Iâ€™m clear on all of the above. And honestly, I felt pretty relaxed about itÂ all.

The hard part of testing onboarding is balancing twoÂ things:

  1. The macro steps (getting you set up, called â€˜set upÂ tasksâ€™)
  2. The micro details that arenâ€™t crucial, but subconsciously push peopleÂ along.

On 1. itâ€™s incredibly hard to prioritise what to put in onboarding. As a rule of thumb, if it positively impacts retention (i.e. when people take [product action] we see they retain better) then AB test it in onboarding to see if itâ€™s a causal relationship, not just a correlation.

On 2, itâ€™s even harder to make decisions of what small details to add. What micro copy will calm users, what images canÂ help.

Individual, isolated tests rarely reach significance on these things. And if youâ€™re not close to the customer, you can end up just adding words, steps and noise that get in theÂ way.

For Runna, the macro stepsÂ are:

  • Set aÂ goal
  • Pick aÂ race
  • Self select your runningÂ ability
  • What days would you like toÂ run?
  • Predict your runningÂ time
  • Pick km/mi

From the copy on these steps, my anxieties around fitting the plan into my week, running a good pace and â€˜will I be readyâ€™ for my half marathon areÂ covered.

Then itâ€™s the micro details that add confidence. If I pick a 5k time thatâ€™s too fast, it tells me the app isnâ€™t built forÂ me.

Which reinforces that I am in the right place, because I cannot run that fast (but I hope to oneÂ day).

The post-onboarding plan introduction takes the level of confidence one step further,Â with:

  • Estimated raceÂ times
  • A guide to the four run types (with a coach video explainer forÂ each)
  • The first of those workouts reflected in my plan (starting with an easy run,Â yay)

The estimated times show me what I can achieve with and without theÂ app:

  • Without Runna: 1hrÂ 59
  • With Runna: 8 minutes faster (1hrÂ 51)

Again imagery being used here to show value at aÂ glance.

Lastly, the copy on â€˜Types of runâ€™ guides is just soÂ simple.

â€˜The purpose of these runs is to recover and freshenÂ upâ€™

No jargon, no running-speak. None of that elite language that puts peopleÂ off.

Just plain old english. And again, none of it feels optimised. Itâ€™s just plain andÂ simple.

Bish bashÂ bosh.

The summary: confidence is what Runna is optimizing for.

By the time I finished onboarding, I hadnâ€™t even started training but already felt more confident about theÂ race.

Thinking back over this flow, the funny thing is that it isnâ€™t particularly sexy. Runna doesnâ€™t try to impressÂ me.

Instead, every choiceâ€Šâ€”â€Šfrom unhurried pacing to clear copyâ€Šâ€”â€Šsignals that this app is serious about getting you to yourÂ goal.

It feels like the restraint on product sexiness or pazazz, and the focus on plain and simple, is what earnsÂ trust.

The irony is that this onboarding doesnâ€™t just onboard you into an app. It onboards you into believing you can actually run theÂ thing.

How to nail onboardingâ€Šâ€”â€Ša case study of Runna was originally published in UX Collective on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
